---
# Let's recap

- What geometry would you use for plotting two numerical variables?
- What geometry would you use for plotting categorical vs continuous variables?
- How can you include a third variable in the plot?

---

# Plotting num vs num vs cat

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center', message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
sinai_covid <- read_csv("Sinai_covid.csv")

ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = age, 
           y = bmi,
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point()
```

---
# Plotting num vs num vs cat vs cat

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center', message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
ggplot(sinai_covid,aes(x = age, 
                       y = bmi,
                       color = facility,
                       shape = sex)) +
  geom_point()
```

---
# Plotting cat vs cat?

- How would you compare smoking_status vs facility?

```{r, out.width=350, out.height=200, fig.align='center',}
ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = smoking_status,
           y = facility)) +
  geom_point()
```

---
# Plotting cat vs cat vs num

- First create the summarized tibble

```{r}
count_smoking <- sinai_covid %>% 
  group_by(facility) %>% 
  count(smoking_status)

count_smoking[1:3,]
```

---

- Plot
```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(count_smoking, 
       aes(x = smoking_status,
           y = facility,
           size = n)) +
  geom_point()
```

---
# Plotting 3 variables (cat-cat-num)

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(count_smoking, 
       aes(x = smoking_status, 
           y = facility,
           size = n, color = n)) +
  geom_point()
```

---
# Let's practice

- Count the number of patients with obesity (0 and 1) per facility 
- Plot the data mapping the size of the dots to the obesity counts

---
# Another way

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ob_count <- sinai_covid %>% 
  group_by(facility) %>% 
  count(obesity)

ggplot(ob_count, aes(x = facility, y = n, 
                     fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col()
```

---

- Obesity must be a "categorical" variable
- Let's treat the variable as factor

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, 
           y = facility, 
           fill = factor(obesity))) +
  geom_col()
```

---

Or replace values

```{r, out.width=500, out.height=300, fig.align='center'}
ob_count <- ob_count %>% 
  mutate(obesity = case_when(obesity == 0 ~ "no",
                             obesity == 1 ~ "yes"))

ggplot(ob_count, aes(x = n, y = facility, 
               fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col()
```

---
# Splitting the bars

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, 
           y = facility, 
           fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge())
```

---
# Adding titles

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, y = facility, 
           fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge()) +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per fcility",
       x = "Number of patients",
       y = "",
       fill = "Obesity")
```


---
# Facets

```{r}
ob_count <- sinai_covid %>% 
  group_by(facility, sex) %>% 
  count(obesity) %>% 
  mutate(obesity = case_when(obesity == 0 ~ "no",
                             obesity == 1 ~ "yes"))

ob_count[1:3,]
```

---
## Facet grid

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, y = facility, 
           fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge()) +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per facility",
       x = "Number of patients",
       y = "",
       fill = "Obesity") +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(sex))
```

---
## Facet grid

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, y = facility, 
           fill = obesity)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge()) +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per facility",
       x = "Number of patients",
       y = "",
       fill = "Obesity") +
  facet_grid(cols = vars(sex))
```

---
## Facet grid

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, y = facility)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per facility",
       x = "Number of patients",
       y = "") +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(obesity),
             cols = vars(sex),
             labeller = label_both)
```

---
## Facet wrap

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = n, y = facility)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per facility",
       x = "Number of patients",
       y = "") +
  facet_wrap(vars(sex, obesity), scales = "free_x",
             labeller = label_both)
```

# Let's practice!

- Count the number of patients depending on their smoking status per ethnic group and asthma status.
- Represent the data on a column plot, color them by asthma status 
- Add a plot title, axis title and change the legend title to remove the underscores
- Split the plots in columns and rows by smoking and asthma status

---
#	Statistical transformations

```{r, out.width=400, out.height=250, fig.align='center'}
sinai_covid %>% 
  mutate(asthma = case_when(asthma == 0 ~ "no",
                            asthma == 1 ~ "yes"),
         diabetes = case_when(diabetes == 0 ~ "no",
                              diabetes == 1 ~ "yes")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = age, y = log10(bmi))) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(vars(diabetes,asthma), scales = "free_y",
             labeller = label_both)
```

# Let's practice!

- Write the code needed to get the following plot:
```{r, echo=FALSE, out.width='70%', fig.align='center'}
sinai_covid %>% 
  mutate(obesity = case_when(obesity == 0 ~ "no",
                            obesity == 1 ~ "yes"),
         diabetes = case_when(diabetes == 0 ~ "no",
                              diabetes == 1 ~ "yes")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = log10(bmi), y = race)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(vars(obesity, diabetes), labeller = label_both) +
  labs(title = "Obesity and diabetes distribution by race",
       y = "")
```

---

- Possible Answer

```{r, eval=FALSE}
sinai_covid %>% 
  mutate(obesity = case_when(obesity == 0 ~ "no",
                            obesity == 1 ~ "yes"),
         diabetes = case_when(diabetes == 0 ~ "no",
                              diabetes == 1 ~ "yes")) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = log10(bmi), y = race)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(vars(obesity, diabetes), 
             labeller = label_both) +
  labs(title = "Obesity and diabetes distribution by race",
       y = "")
```

---
# Scales

```{r, out.width='50%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid, aes(x = age, y = bmi, 
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = 2)
```

---

- Invert scale direction

```{r, out.width='50%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = age, y = bmi, 
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = 3, direction = -1)
```

---

- Using manual scale

```{r, out.width='50%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = age, y = bmi, 
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue","darkgreen",
                                "orange", "pink"))
```

---

- Using manual scale. Look for "html color picker" on Google browser

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = age, y = bmi, 
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#eb4034", "#d19617", 
                                         "#429642",
                                "#31d5de","#3148de"))
```

---
# Customized position

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
count_smoking <- sinai_covid %>% 
  group_by(asthma, sex) %>% 
  count(smoking_status) %>% 
  mutate(asthma = case_when(asthma == 0 ~ "no",
                            asthma == 1 ~ "yes"),
         asthma = factor(asthma, levels = c("yes", "no"))
         )

count_smoking[1:3,]
```

---
```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(count_smoking,
       aes(x = smoking_status, 
           y = n,
           fill = asthma)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge()) +
  scale_x_discrete(limits = c("YES", "NEVER", "QUIT")) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("yes" = "red",
                               "no" = "blue")) +
  facet_wrap(vars(sex))
```

---
#	Coordinate systems 

- coord_flip 

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid,
       aes(x = age, y = bmi)) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_flip()
```

---

- coord_fixed 

Makes x and y axis proportional to each other

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid,
       aes(x = age, y = bmi)) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_fixed()
```

---

- coord_polar 

Used for navigation, considers direction and angle

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid,
       aes(x = age, y = bmi)) +
  geom_point() +
  coord_polar()
```

---
# Themes

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(sinai_covid, 
       aes(x = age, y = bmi, 
           color = facility)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw()
```

---

```{r, out.width='40%', fig.align='center'}
ggplot(ob_count, 
       aes(x = facility, y = n, fill = factor(obesity))) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge()) +
  labs(title = "Obesity incidence per facility",
       x = "",
       y = "Number of patients",
       fill = "Obesity (0 = no, 1 = yes)") +
  theme_bw(base_size = 12) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) 
```
